author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Henri Brings Heavy Rains to New York City
description: The New York area escaped the worst of the tropical storm, though a much-anticipated concert was cut short.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: September Vocabulary Challenge: Discover a Word in The New York Times
description: What intriguing vocabulary words can you find in The Times? Learn a new word and tell us what you find out about it by Sept. 30.
content: How often in your daily reading do you come across words you don’t know but would like to? Do you ever stop and look them up? How often do these kinds of words become part of your own vocabulary?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: Educators Will Be First N.Y.C. Workers to Face Full Vaccine Mandate
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Monday that all Department of Education employees must have received at least one dose of a coronavirus vaccine by Sept. 27.
content: New York City will require all Department of Education employees to have received at least one dose of a coronavirus vaccine by Sept. 27, Mayor Bill de Blasio said Monday. The announcement represents a major step in the effort to fully reopen the country’s largest school district next month, and a significant escalation of the mayor’s push to vaccinate more New Yorkers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Katie Glueck
title: Cuomo Blames ‘Political Pressure and Media Frenzy’ in Farewell Speech
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo, who will be succeeded by Kathy Hochul on Tuesday, cast his resignation as the forced outcome of a “political and media stampede.”
content: On his last day in office, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, a three-term Democrat once envisioned as a national standard-bearer for his party, appeared alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Jim Tankersley
title: Democrats Scrounge for Votes to Pass $3.5 Trillion Budget Plan
description: With moderates balking, Speaker Nancy Pelosi was working to secure their support for the budget. Democrats ultimately scrapped tentative plans for a vote late Monday.
content: WASHINGTON — Democratic leaders worked feverishly on Monday to cobble together the votes needed to push their $3.5 trillion budget blueprint through the House, facing an internal revolt from moderates who have vowed to block the measure until a $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure plan is passed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Global response to Afghan refugees.
content: President Biden said on Sunday that his administration might extend his Aug. 31 deadline for removing all American troops from Afghanistan, and he pledged that all evacuated Afghan allies would be given a home in the U.S. after they were screened at bases in other countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: 18 Are Expelled or Resign From Naval Academy Amid Cheating Inquiry
description: When the academy administered a physics test last year, it had to be flexible because of Covid-19 restrictions. It later learned that dozens of midshipmen had used outside resources during the exam.
content: Eighteen midshipmen resigned or were expelled from the United States Naval Academy after an investigation found that students there had cheated on a physics final exam last year, the academy said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: The top U.S. officer in Afghanistan talks with the Taliban almost every day.
description: Other officers have also engaged with Taliban commanders on specific security and threat reduction issues, a partnership of necessity after 20 years of war.
content: WASHINGTON — On the ground in Kabul, Rear Adm. Peter G. Vasely, a former member of the Navy SEALs who is now the top U.S. military officer in Afghanistan, talks daily or near daily with his Taliban counterparts regarding security measures at the airport, Pentagon officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christiaan Triebert
title: Videos show a rush to destroy U.S. equipment as Kabul fell.
description: The New York Times verified videos and photos taken by U.S. contractors of garbage bins full of destroyed equipment and staff burning documents as workers fled the U.S. embassy.
content: Garbage bins overflowing with destroyed equipment. Smashed computer parts scattered across the ground. Diplomatic workers burning documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas, Winston Choi-Schagrin and Tariro Mzezewa
title: ‘Our People Need Help’: Devastation in Tennessee, as Experts Warn of Flooding Risks
description: At least 21 people were confirmed dead and about 10 remained unaccounted for after catastrophic flash flooding that scientists say climate change makes more common.
content: WAVERLY, Tenn. — With floodwaters rising rapidly, 15-year-old Lily Bryant and her older sister managed to find some wooden debris to cling to, but it offered only short-term relief. The makeshift raft hit a tree and split in two.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: Lorde on Late Night and ‘American Horror Story’
description: The musician Lorde has a residency on CBS’s “Late Late Show With James Corden.” And a new season of “American Horror Story” begins on FX.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Aug. 23-29. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Learn 60 New Vocabulary Words With These Imaginative Student Videos
description: Expand your vocabulary with videos from winners of our 15-Second Vocabulary Video Contest.
content: Over the past eight years of our Vocabulary Video Contest, students have produced thousands of lively, original videos in which they define a Word of the Day in under 15 seconds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
title: A hospital finds an unlikely group opposing vaccination: its workers.
description: Outside Staten Island University Hospital this week, as passing cars and fire trucks honked supportively, some employees chanted, “I am not a lab rat!” They were among the nurses, medical technicians, infection control officers and other staff at the hospital who are denouncing efforts to push them to get vaccinated.
content: Outside Staten Island University Hospital this week, as passing cars and fire trucks honked supportively, some employees chanted, “I am not a lab rat!” They were among the nurses, medical technicians, infection control officers and other staff at the hospital who are denouncing efforts to push them to get vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Talking Cookbooks With Adeena Sussman
description: The author will discuss Rosh Hashana and suggest recipes during a virtual event hosted by a new food-focused cultural center in Tel Aviv.
content: Asif: Culinary Institute of Israel, a new food-focused cultural center with a library, test kitchen, rooftop farm, gallery and cafe, opened last month in Tel Aviv. It’s the work of Naama Shefi, who created and runs the nonprofit Jewish Food Society in the United States to foster Jewish food culture, and Terry Kassel, chairwoman of the board of Start-Up Nation Central, an Israeli nonprofit promoting innovation. For one of its first programs, the cookbook author Adeena Sussman will discuss food for the Rosh Hashana holiday and suggest recipes from cookbooks she wants to see in Asif’s library.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and Kellen Browning
title: A Judge Declared California’s Gig Worker Law Unconstitutional. Now What?
description: The law, the result of a $200 million proposition fight last year, ensures that workers like Uber and Lyft drivers are considered independent contractors.
content: Emboldened by a California election victory that maintained the independence of their drivers last year, gig economy companies like Uber and Lyft have in recent months accelerated a push for what they call a “third way” of working, a classification of independent gig workers who receive limited benefits without gaining employee status.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Megan K. Stack
title: Taliban Reject Extended Deadline as U.S. Races to Finish Evacuation
description: Tens of thousands are still hoping for rescue, with priority recently being given to Americans over Afghan allies, according to a U.S. official and those involved in the effort.
content: As a desperate U.S. effort to evacuate Americans from Afghanistan gained momentum on Monday, Taliban leaders rejected a suggestion from President Biden that American forces might remain past an Aug. 31 deadline to complete the operation, injecting fresh urgency into an already frantic process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: Biden and the Fed Wanted a Hot Economy. There’s Risk of Getting Burned.
description: So far, in a real-world test of a new approach to economic policy, prices have been rising faster than wages.
content: There is a big idea in economic policy that has become ascendant in recent years: Great things can be achieved for American workers if the economy is allowed to run hot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Atticus Lish’s Second Novel Is a Brooding Heartbreaker
description: “The War for Gloria,” Lish’s follow-up to the acclaimed “Preparation for the Next Life,” is the powerful story of a mother and son facing her mortal illness.
content: Atticus Lish’s second novel, “The War for Gloria,” is, by and large, a monster — solemn, punishing, kinetic, in easy contact with dark areas of the psyche, and yet heartbreaking in its portrait of a mother and son facing her mortal illness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Don’t Like FIFA’s Schedule? Go Ahead and Appeal. To FIFA.
description: A dispute about World Cup qualifying games has highlighted the power soccer’s governing body holds over clubs, and how little recourse they have.
content: A meeting was called, discussions were held, and groups representing some of the world’s biggest soccer clubs and leagues were given a chance to have their say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Madeleine Ngo
title: What an Adult Tricycle Says About the World’s Bottleneck Problems
description: The supply-chain problems rocking companies may get worse heading into the holidays, as delays continue to snarl global trade and shipping prices jump even higher.
content: Catrike has 500 of its three-wheeled bikes sitting in its workshop in Orlando, Fla., nearly ready to be sent to expectant dealers. The recumbent trikes have been waiting for months for rear derailleurs, a small but crucial part that is built in Taiwan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Full approval for the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine.
content: On Monday morning, the F.D.A. granted full approval to the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for people 16 and up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Damour
title: How to Support Teenagers as They Head Back to School
description: Adolescents are readying for the next step in a seemingly endless set of challenges. Here’s how to help them regulate their emotions.
content: Many teenagers are feeling understandably upset as they face a third school year disrupted by Covid-19. Some are frustrated about the return to masks and other precautions. Others are nervous about how they will stay safe at school, or worried about eagerly anticipated activities being postponed or canceled. They might be angry about the seeming never-endingness of the pandemic. As adults in their lives, how should we be trying to help them handle all of this turmoil?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: In William Maxwell’s Fiction, a Vivid, Varied Tableau of Midwestern Life
description: Though his novels and short stories — published over six decades, beginning in 1934 — are set in an older, more decorous America, he grapples with themes that feel shockingly contemporary.
content: “OF THE LITERARY ARTS, the one most practiced in Draperville was history.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winston Choi-Schagrin and John Schwartz
title: What role does climate change play in disasters like the Tennessee flooding?
description: “This is exactly the type of event we expect to see with increasing frequency in a warming climate,” one expert said.
content: In the past 48 hours, parts of Tennessee have been swept by record-breaking rainfall and unexpected flash flooding that has killed at least 21 people and left dozens missing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Billie Eilish Earns a Third Week at No. 1, Narrowly
description: “Happier Than Ever” beat out Doja Cat’s “Planet Her” on the Billboard album chart by a margin of 1,000 equivalent album sales.
content: After a tight weekly race, Billie Eilish holds at No. 1 on Billboard’s album chart for a third time, just ahead of releases from earlier this year by Doja Cat and Olivia Rodrigo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: T. Rex Was Fearsome but May Have Been a Picky Eater
description: The jaw of the Tyrannosaurus Rex had sensitive nerves that may have allowed it to differentiate between parts of its prey, a new study found.
content: Was the Tyrannosaurus Rex a foodie?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Rice University says a testing glitch led to high rates of false positives.
description: The worrisome test results had prompted the university to switch to remote classes.
content: Rice University, where more than 95 percent of students are vaccinated, announced a move to remote classes last week after testing showed an alarmingly high number of community members with breakthrough coronavirus infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten and Callie Holtermann
title: 14 Ways to Learn Vocabulary and Explore Language With The New York Times
description: Eight practical ideas for understanding new words in context — plus six ideas for thinking more deeply about the relationships between language and culture.
content: Our vocabulary offerings aim to convince students that learning a word’s definition opens the door to the real fun: spotting patterns in a word’s usage, interrogating its shades of meaning and incorporating it into one’s own vocabulary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: Cathie Wood’s Calling
description: The high-profile tech investor’s origin story is unique in the industry.
content: Cathie Wood, the hottest fund manager on Wall Street, didn’t rise to prominence in the typical way. A common path to success for money managers is to land larger and larger accounts, transitioning from managing billions of dollars from wealthy individuals to handling trillions from pension funds, endowments and sovereign wealth funds. Wood has taken the reverse route, explains The Times’s Matt Phillips in a big new profile of the fund manager.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall, Austin Ramzy and Sharif Hassan
title: Forced to leave his home, former President Hamid Karzai remains in Kabul despite the risks.
description: He and the Taliban have long been enemies, but he has stayed in Afghanistan, hoping to work with the militants and help shape a new government.
content: Last week, former President Hamid Karzai stood outside his home in Kabul to record a video message, surrounded by his daughters, and said that he would stay in the Afghan capital with his family to try to coordinate with the Taliban for a peaceful transition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Gambling on Trevor Bauer Is Not the Dodger Way
description: The team signed the 2020 National League Cy Young Award winner in anticipation of another World Series run. It ignored his troubling background, at odds with the franchise’s legacy.
content: LOS ANGELES — What a mess. What an awful, ugly mess. And what a stain on baseball and one of its most venerable teams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz and Eduardo Medina
title: Henri spawns tornadoes in Massachusetts and continues to deluge parts of the Northeast.
description: Meteorologists are warning of flash flooding as up to two more inches of rain are expected in central New England on Monday night and early Tuesday morning.
content: The remnants of Tropical Storm Henri stalled over New England on Monday, dropping yet more rain and spawning three tornadoes in central Massachusetts that caused some damage but no deaths or injuries, according to the National Weather Service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: 5 Diet and Lifestyle Measures to Ward Off Heartburn
description: Taking steps to combat acid reflux can help minimize the use of potentially dangerous drugs.
content: The childhood admonition to refrain from swimming for an hour after eating, ostensibly to avoid cramp, is not nearly long enough for me anymore. I now have to wait at least two hours before attempting any vigorous activity, or chores that involve bending over, to avoid the miserable sensation of acid reflux, commonly recognized by its frequent symptom of heartburn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Alan Heller, Who Made Plastic Housewares Beautiful, Dies at 81
description: For designers like Mario Bellini and Massimo and Lella Vignelli, Mr. Heller produced domestic objects that became models of modern design.
content: Alan Heller, the manufacturer of elegant, often whimsical but always affordable housewares and furniture that married high design with prosaic plastic, died on Aug. 13 at his home in Manhattan. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Yes, the Owner of a Movie Theater Chain Feels Bad for Me
description: The Alamo Drafthouse Cinema chain filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy during the pandemic, but its founder, Tim League, is still bullish on the future of moviegoing.
content: When Kara Swisher wrote a column declaring her love for Vin Diesel and predicting that we will not be returning to movie theaters, Tim League felt sorry for her. He’s the founder of Alamo Drafthouse Cinema, a luxury movie theater chain that opened in Austin over 20 years ago and has since expanded nationally. The pandemic has not been kind to the company, which he notes was in “dire” condition by December and filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy earlier this year. But League still remains bullish about his industry and the value of the theater experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Will the Pandemic Make Los Angeles More Pedestrian-Friendly?
description: Outdoor dining and slow streets programs are chipping away at Southern California’s deference to cars.
content: PASADENA — Along bustling Colorado Boulevard, friends clinked wine glasses in the glow of twinkle lights. A few blocks away, another group of diners ate beside massive potted plants as a crooner serenaded them from onstage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: Zen and the Art of #VanLife Influencing
description: Are influencers the new hippies?
content: For the past year, I have been trying to buy a conversion van. My reasons are silly and expected: pandemic claustrophobia mixed with pandemic romanticism about the outdoors. About 10 years ago, I was a competent-enough surfer, but I can barely paddle out in waist-high waves anymore. A conversion van, I reasoned, would allow me to drive the 40 or so minutes to the beach, where I could learn to surf again and type while staring out at the water. When my daughter grows old enough to swim in the ocean, I imagine long camping trips up and down the Pacific Coast, everywhere from La Jolla to Westport.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Aug. 23, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 23, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos and Clifford Krauss
title: Chevron and CVS mandate coronavirus vaccines.
description: Chevron’s requirement applies to employees who travel internationally and expatriates, as well as the offshore work force in the Gulf of Mexico and some onshore support personnel.
content: CVS Health and the oil and gas giant Chevron said on Monday that they would mandate coronavirus vaccines for some employees, joining other large corporations that are making similar demands on office workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Sea Scallops Farmed in Maine Aren’t Just Sustainable. They’re Helping Their Habitat.
description: There are only a handful of these farms in the United States, most run by fishing families in Maine. But their number is growing.
content: STONINGTON, Maine — On a damp, cloudy morning in April, Marsden Brewer drove his 38-foot lobster boat out into the middle of Penobscot Bay. Other than a few buoys and the occasional gull, the water was calm and empty — a vast, gray expanse leading to pine-topped islands in the distance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Robin
title: R. Murray Schafer, Composer Who Heard Nature’s Music, Dies at 88
description: He delved into the relationship between sound and the environment. Many of his compositions incorporated the music of the natural world.
content: R. Murray Schafer, a Canadian composer and writer who brought the concept of the “soundscape” to widespread recognition and pioneered the field of acoustic ecology — the relationship between sound, people and the environment — died on Aug. 14 at his home near Peterborough, Ontario. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Rod Gilbert, Hockey Hall of Famer Known as Mr. Ranger, Dies at 80
description: Gilbert played his entire N.H.L. career with New York and is the franchise’s only player to score more than 400 goals.
content: Rod Gilbert, a quicksilver Hall of Fame forward for the New York Rangers who more than 40 years after his career ended remains the team’s leading scorer, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Stengel
title: The Taliban Want You to Keep Your Phone On
description: They employed social media to cultivate an image of strength within Afghanistan while projecting an air of legitimacy to the outside world.
content: On Aug. 14, a day before armed fighters swarmed into Kabul, a Twitter account for one of the Taliban’s magazines posted a video of six nervous Afghan government soldiers sitting in a truck surrounded by Taliban warriors. The post included a snippet of text, in Pashto, one of the two main languages of Afghanistan: “While the mujahedeen behave generously to soldiers, the children of the village threw stones at them and called them dogs. That’s what happens in response to their atrocities.” The same day, a spokesman for the Taliban posted another Twitter message, this time in English, promising that the group would create “a secure environment” for all diplomats, embassies and nonprofits, both domestic and international. It ended with the Arabic benediction “Inshallah” (God willing).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Biden’s Foreign Policy Priorities.
description: How Afghanistan fits into President Biden’s foreign policy plans, and how he could salvage the withdrawal.
content: Before the Taliban marched through the gates of Kabul, before the desperate scenes of a makeshift airlift, before a baby was passed over the barbed wire on the airport walls, President Biden had one simple way of framing his decision to end the endless war in Afghanistan: national interest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bridgette Bartlett Royall
title: How to Plan a Surprise Wedding
description: Secret weddings are not just for celebrities. Get the inside scoop from industry experts on how to seamlessly pull off your own.
content: Surprise weddings aren’t new, especially among the rich and famous. But during the pandemic, their appeal has been gaining in popularity. Following a year and a half of quarantining, couples seem to be craving more intimacy and personalization and less pomp and circumstance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz, Nicole Hong, Patrick McGeehan and Gabriela Bhaskar
title: New York’s Economy, Poised for Comeback, Finds Setback Instead
description: The Delta variant has upended events, office reopenings and travel, raising new challenges for service businesses and their workers.
content: For New York City and its trillion-dollar economy, September was supposed to mark a return to normal, a moment when Broadway theaters reopened, stores and restaurants hummed, and tourists and office workers again filled the streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Guadagnino
title: A Performance Piece That Pairs Painted Waves Alongside Real Ones
description: On view in Newport, R.I., Melissa McGill’s latest is an ode to nature and a reminder of our debt to it.
content: For the first two weeks of August, Melissa McGill’s studio was beneath a white canopy tent pitched on the undulating backyard lawn of Rough Point, one of the impossibly large Gilded Age homes facing Newport, R.I.’s Bellevue Avenue on one side and the Atlantic on the other. Working mornings and afternoons, the artist made 50 acrylic paintings of the ocean, attempting to capture its look and mood in real time. The works, some of which are layered with cheerful streaks of blue and white while others feature diluted grays, are all dated, and together make up a kind of diary of the sea. Perhaps this all sounds a little old-fashioned — after all, the Atlantic has been popular with en plein-air painters since at least the late 19th century — but in fact, McGill’s works, which were done on sheets of recycled ocean plastic ranging from 25 to 45 feet in length, are part of a deeply contemporary project: a collaborative performance piece, one meant to raise awareness about rising sea levels, called “In the Waves.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Our 9th Annual 15-Second Vocabulary Video Challenge
description: We invite middle and high school students to create a short video that defines or teaches any of the words in our Word of the Day collection. Contest Dates: Dec. 1, 2021-Jan. 12, 2022.
content: The Vocabulary Video Contest is one of our most beloved annual traditions. Working on a site devoted to the news can sometimes be grim, but running this contest has always guaranteed our staff at least a few weeks every year when judging submissions has mostly just meant cracking up at our desks. (Or, this year, on Zoom.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Svetlana Tikhanovskaya
title: No One in Europe Is Safe From My Country’s Dictator
description: All democratic countries have a stake in the future of  Belarus.
content: Just over a year ago, on Aug. 9, 2020, I stood in Belarus’s presidential election against Aleksandr Lukashenko. The dictator, who has ruled the country for 27 years with an iron fist, stole victory from us, setting off widespread protests. We united in a national pro-democracy movement to demand the release of all political prisoners, an end to state violence and a free and fair election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gwen Knapp
title: Paralympics to Open With Empty Stands but a Bigger Stage
description: Television exposure and new interest from sponsors are raising hopes that the Games can build on their momentum.
content: TOKYO — One Paralympic swimmer ended up training in the chilly Arkansas River for a while after the coronavirus pandemic cut off her access to a pool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Afghan Refugees Find a Harsh and Unfriendly Border in Turkey
description: Even before the last week’s harrowing scenes at the Kabul airport, thousands of Afghans were fleeing over land through Iran to Turkey. But they are being pushed back.
content: VAN, Turkey — In the days before the Taliban took Kabul, an Afghan woman was doubled over sobbing on a bench in a bus station in eastern Turkey, her children wailing at her feet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Scoring Biden’s ‘Care Economy’ Plan
description: If human capital is an asset, how should Congress measure the payoff?
content: One justification for the Biden administration’s “care economy” agenda is that it’s an investment in human capital that will pay dividends in the long run. The idea is that spending now on early childhood education and child care will make today’s children into productive workers who will earn more money, pay more taxes and thus help reduce future budget deficits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Russian Journalists Meet a Crackdown With Dark Humor, and Subscribers
description: Meduza, a leading independent news site, fights back with jokes and a stunning donation campaign. But can it stand up to the Russian state?
content: RIGA, Latvia — There’s a certain kind of American podcast where two young journalists investigate their own medium-size problems, laugh a lot, interview their moms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Régis Defurnaux
title: On the Move With Mongolia’s Nomadic Reindeer Herders
description: Facing growing uncertainties, the Dukha people are being forced to make difficult decisions about their traditions and their future.
content: A morning mist filled the valley near Hatgal, a small village at the southern tip of Lake Khovsgol in north central Mongolia. Glancing at the figures between the fragrant pines and larches, I could hardly distinguish the silhouettes of the reindeer from those of their herders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: Spike Lee, Exultant at the ‘Epicenter’
description: The filmmaker’s epic new documentary series, “NYC Epicenters 9/11-2021½,” is an alternately mournful and irreverent tribute to New York.
content: Spike Lee, like the city he’s from, exudes a kind of brash resilience. His resting facial expression says “Try me.” In New York, it can feel as if trials await around every corner. Hardship here is a kind of birthright, whether of the quotidian variety (the gantlet of garbage smells in the summertime) or the catastrophic (the Sept. 11 attacks, the first spring of the Covid-19 pandemic).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mimi Swartz
title: How Far Are Texans From Open Rebellion Against Greg Abbott?
description: Voters should take “personal responsibility” and find a better person to run Texas.
content: HOUSTON — A law school classmate of our governor once insisted to me that Greg Abbott was more dangerous than his predecessor Rick Perry because he was smart. I would say that the events of the past few months lend considerable support to the first part of the sentence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: The Orioles Are Bad and It Just Might Get Worse
description: With 18 straight losses, and a tough stretch of games, Baltimore could set a futility record. The stripped-down roster being part of a larger plan doesn’t make it any easier to watch.
content: Dylan Bundy tried his best to give a promising vision of the future. This was at spring training in 2019, when the Baltimore Orioles had finished the previous season as the worst team in the major leagues. They were bad and they knew it, but teams like that can always cling to hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Even Billy Joel Mocked ‘We Didn’t Start the Fire.’ I Loved It.
description: As a 4-year-old, our critic couldn’t get enough of this manic 1989 hit, a crash course in U.S. history. Now the song lives on in parodies and memes.
content: As a music critic, I’ve long been fascinated by people’s first favorite songs. Not songs made for children, or the kinds of songs we self-consciously broadcast our allegiance to after we’ve developed the filters of taste, personal identity and critical perspective. I’m talking about those early formative encounters with the vast world of popular culture — the initial, primeval jolt that this song is somehow more special than the rest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Capitol Police clear officer who shot rioter, saying he may have saved lives.
description: “The actions of the officer in this case potentially saved members and staff from serious injury and possible death,” the agency said.
content: WASHINGTON — The U.S. Capitol Police announced on Monday that they had cleared a lieutenant who fatally shot a rioter inside the Capitol during the Jan. 6 attack, after an extensive investigation found that he acted lawfully and potentially saved lawmakers and aides from serious harm or death.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Style of Kanye West’s ‘Donda’ Era
description: How West has used fashion to signify musical evolution, how he’s been regarded by the fashion industry and how other musicians are following in his footsteps.
content: Kanye West may or may not be imminently releasing “Donda,” his 10th solo album, but over the course of the past few weeks, this era in his career has already established its own signature aesthetic: all black, military, asceticism on an epic scale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Broadway Power Brokers Pledge Diversity Changes as Theaters Reopen
description: To address Black artists’ concerns, the pact calls for forgoing all-white creative teams, renaming theaters for Black artists and establishing diversity rules for the Tonys.
content: Fifteen months after the George Floyd protests called renewed attention to racism in many areas of society, some of the most powerful players on Broadway have signed a pact pledging to strengthen the industry’s diversity practices as theaters reopen following the lengthy shutdown prompted by the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Michael Simon Johnson, Sydney Harper, Chelsea Daniel, Annie Brown, Soraya Shockley, Robert Jimison, Dave Shaw, Lisa Chow, Chris Wood and Dan Powell
title: Children and Covid: Your Questions, Answered
description: As schools reopen, we respond to queries from parents about how the coronavirus will affect the return to classrooms.
content: When will vaccinations realistically be available for children under 12? How dangerous is the coronavirus for youngsters? What symptoms should parents be looking for?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘The Future,’ ‘Cheap Thrills’ and More Offbeat Streaming Gems
description: Looking for something different to watch? Take a chance on one of these under-the-radar selections.
content: In the quieter corners of your subscription streaming services this month, you’ll find inspiring documentaries, unpredictable genre movies, indie dramas inspired by both headlines and history books, and ingenious riffs on “Hamlet,” Huck Finn and the slasher genre.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Stout
title: Anthony M. Scotto, Former Union Power on the Docks, Dies at 87
description: He rose to leadership in the longshoremen’s union as a polished reformer, but the U.S. called him a Mafia boss, and he served prison time in a racketeering case.
content: Anthony M. Scotto, a former leader of the longshoremen’s union whose polished manners and soft-spoken approach made him seem out of place in the turbulent, often corrupt world of the waterfront until he himself went to prison for labor racketeering, has died. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson and Emily Palmer
title: Woman Says R. Kelly Abused Her and Pressured Her to Have an Abortion
description: The second accuser to testify against the disgraced R&B star said he pressured her to have an abortion, as the second week of Mr. Kelly’s trial began.
content: Zel was 17 and an aspiring singer when she first encountered R. Kelly, and she hoped that the R&B star could help jump-start her professional career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: A Covid outbreak delays a draft report on Arizona Republicans’ widely criticized election review.
description: The chief executive of Cyber Ninjas, the company in charge of Republicans’ politically expedient review of 2020 results in Maricopa County, was one of three people who were “quite sick,” the State Senate president said.
content: A draft report on a much-ridiculed review of the 2020 election results in Arizona’s largest county has been delayed by a Covid-19 outbreak on the team preparing the analysis, the Republican president of the Arizona State Senate said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Fleeing Afghans are unable to find refuge in Turkey.
content: Weeks before Kabul fell to the Taliban, tens of thousands of Afghans were already fleeing the country each week. Many of them traveled 1,400 miles across Iran, hoping to make their way to Europe. But the migrants were met with sharp resistance at Turkey’s border, where thousands of Afghans were massed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien
title: Taiwan begins using a homegrown vaccine after months of shortages in imports.
description: Critics say they worry that the vaccine, which has completed Phase 2 trials, is being used before its effectiveness and safety have been proved.
content: Taiwan started administering its first locally developed Covid-19 vaccine on Monday after months of struggles to get sufficient supplies of doses from major foreign vaccine makers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Yu Young Jin
title: Apple and Google’s Fight in Seoul Tests Biden in Washington
description: A proposal in the South Korean legislature is an early test of how forcefully the Biden administration will defend the companies abroad while trying to trim their power at home.
content: WASHINGTON — For months, Apple and Google have been fighting a bill in the South Korean legislature that they say could imperil their lucrative app store businesses. The companies have appealed directly to South Korean lawmakers, government officials and the public to try to block the legislation, which is expected to face a crucial vote this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Republicans Have Gone Too Far in the Region Hit Hardest by Covid
description: Mask mandates protect children only when masking is universal. This is not a hard concept to understand.
content: NASHVILLE — In case you’re wondering how things are going here in the Delta Rising region of the United States, I regret to report that things are going badly. Very, very badly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Australia tells Afghan refugees: ‘Do not attempt an illegal boat journey.’
description: As Australia scrambles to evacuate citizens and visa holders from Kabul, it has also started an advertising campaign to deter Afghan refugees from trying to reach Australia by boat, promising that they will have “zero chance of success.”
content: As Australia scrambles to evacuate citizens and visa holders from Kabul, it has also started an advertising campaign to deter Afghan refugees from trying to reach Australia by boat, promising that they will have “zero chance of success.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Seeking Early Signals of Dementia in Driving and Credit Scores
description: The pathologies underlying brain decline can begin years before symptoms emerge. Can everyday behavior provide warning?
content: Learning your odds of eventually developing dementia — a pressing concern for many, especially those with a family history of it — requires medical testing and counseling. But what if everyday behavior, like overlooking a couple of credit card payments or habitually braking while driving, could foretell your risk?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danya Issawi
title: Telfar Wants to Know if You Can Spot the Biggest Cat
description: In an effort to combat bots, the brand has made it more difficult to “Captcha” its shopping bags. Too difficult, perhaps.
content: If the clock was ticking and you were tasked with picking out the biggest cat from a series of thumbnail photos of felines, could you do it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: The Fed’s Jackson Hole meeting and a key inflation reading: What’s coming this week.
description: The Federal Reserve’s annual economic symposium will be held virtually. Jerome H. Powell will speak on Friday and is expected to reveal details about how and when the central bank intends to wind down its bond-buying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Cow Parade Returns to N.Y.C., but Please Don’t Steal Them This Time
description: A public art exhibition with 78 fiberglass cows in the boroughs may be scaled down from 21 years ago, but the herd is delighting passers-by.
content: The cows are back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Virtual Cooking Class for the High Holy Days
description: Jake Cohen, the author of “Jew-ish: Reinvented Recipes From a Modern Mensch,” will lead an event at the 92nd Street Y.
content: In today’s Covid-racked society, small, carefully orchestrated family gatherings are especially precious during the Jewish High Holy Days. In a virtual program by the 92nd Street Y, Jake Cohen, a chef and the author of “Jew-ish: Reinvented Recipes From a Modern Mensch,” will discuss the importance of family and togetherness for the holidays with Rabbi Samantha Frank, the director of Jewish education at the 92nd Street Y. He will also demonstrate how to make honey-baked Brie with apples.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Tool Caddies
description: Because it’s nearly fall: Time to get organized.
content: Sometimes it’s the smallest things that are the hardest to organize. What are you supposed to do with all that clutter — those extra pencils, paper clips, sewing needles, screwdrivers or whatever else you have on hand — short of sweeping it into a drawer and trying to forget about it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebekah O'Dell
title: Making Vocabulary Instruction Active With Language Field Guides
description: Starting with our Word of the Day feature, students in a Virginia middle school “learn to think like linguistic ethnographers” as they explore language.
content: To help us celebrate Vocabulary Week here on The Learning Network, we asked the English teacher and writer Rebekah O’Dell to share an idea that has transformed instruction for her middle school students at St. Michael’s Episcopal School in Richmond, Va. She writes that creating what she calls language field guides has made her students into “explorers, mining words for nuanced meaning” instead of passive recipients taking in basic definitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Mayim Bialik will fill in as a ‘Jeopardy!’ guest host.
description: She will replace Mike Richards, who stepped down as host of the game show amid furor over sexist and offensive comments he made on a podcast several years ago.
content: The sitcom star Mayim Bialik will temporarily take over weeknight hosting duties at “Jeopardy!” as the venerable quiz show regroups in the wake of last week’s departure of its new host, Mike Richards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik and Helene Cooper
title: With F.D.A. approval, Pentagon and others add vaccine requirements.
description: After the decision by Food and Drug Administration, some institutions are seeing a green light for mandates.
content: Full federal approval for the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine for those 16 and older is opening the way for institutions like the military, corporate employers, hospitals and school districts to announce vaccine mandates for their employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winston Choi-Schagrin
title: Wildfires are ravaging forests set aside to soak up greenhouse gases.
description: The forests were protected from logging in programs designed to help fight global warming.
content: The wildfires in the American West are burning vast expanses of specially protected forests — those that are part of carbon-offset projects meant to counterbalance the carbon dioxide pollution being pumped into the atmosphere by human activity.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: France to Honor Baker With Panthéon Burial
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 23, 2021.
content: “How could a woman who came from a discriminated and very poor background achieve her destiny and become a world star? That was possible in France at a time when it was not in the United States.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: Did the War in Afghanistan Have to Happen?
description: In 2001, when the Taliban were weak and ready to surrender, the U.S. passed on a deal. Nearly 20 years later, the Taliban hold all the cards.
content: Taliban fighters brandished Kalashnikovs and shook their fists in the air after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, defying American warnings that if they did not hand over Osama Bin Laden, their country would be bombed to smithereens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Hochul Appoints 2 Women to Key Posts in Her Cabinet
description: Lt. Gov. Kathy Hochul, who will become the first female governor of New York on Tuesday, selected experienced political aides to fill her top two administration posts.
content: A day before Kathy Hochul becomes the first female governor of New York State, she announced that her top two aides will be women, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: The Sports Desk Finds Freedom Outside the News Cycle
description: Reporters and editors were told to interpret the theme of freedom, and find a subject.
content: Freedom is quitting competitive swimming to chase another dream. Freedom is free agency. Freedom is an unincorporated community of about 200 people straddling the Wyoming-Idaho line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: 2 New York Judges Ordered Defendants to Get Vaccinated. Can They Do That?
description: The judges’ unusual orders came as the city confronts the Delta variant and a sizable portion of the population appears resistant to being vaccinated.
content: The defendant was charged with a number of minor crimes, including drug possession and shoplifting. He was prepared to plead guilty, and prosecutors agreed. But a Bronx judge approving the deal added his own unusual condition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: 2 Months of Rain in a Day and a Half: New York City Sets Records
description: It’s already the second-wettest summer in city history, thanks to Tropical Storm Henri.
content: Did you hear it rained a lot the other day?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: The U.S. Is Getting a Crash Course in Scientific Uncertainty
description: As the pandemic takes an unexpected direction, Americans again must reckon with twists in scientific understanding of the virus.
content: When the coronavirus surfaced last year, no one was prepared for it to invade every aspect of daily life for so long, so insidiously. The pandemic has forced Americans to wrestle with life-or-death choices every day of the past 18 months — and there’s no end in sight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Cruise Passenger Dies From Covid, Testing Industry Plans
description: The passenger and 26 crew members aboard the Carnival Vista tested positive for the coronavirus and the passenger later died. The company says its protocols successfully stopped further spread.
content: As the highly contagious Delta variant surges across the world, the health and safety protocols established for cruise ships are being put to the test. Over two weeks in late July and early August, 27 coronavirus infections were identified aboard the Carnival Vista cruise ship sailing out of Galveston, Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Julianne Nicholson Didn’t Know Who the Killer Was, Either
description: Her shattering performance in “Mare of Easttown” brought her first Emmy nomination. “Everything just landed in the right way for this to be the role that caught people’s imagination,” she said.
content: Voting is underway for the 73rd Primetime Emmys, and this week we’re talking to several first-time Emmy nominees. The awards will be presented Sept. 19 on CBS.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gerald Eskenazi
title: Rod Gilbert, Known as Mr. Ranger, Warmed New York to Ice Hockey
description: The Rangers great, whose death at the age of 80 was announced on Sunday, was more than a sensational player and a good guy, writes a former Times hockey reporter.
content: Rod Gilbert became the face of the Rangers when hockey was virtually a niche sport in New York. But the flashy right wing, whose death at the age of 80 was announced on Sunday, helped turn the club into an attraction that often rivaled their Madison Square Garden co-tenants, the Knicks, allowing the Rangers to join the Mets, Yankees, Jets and Giants as stars of the city’s sports scene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Father and Sons Are Charged in $21 Million Lottery Fraud
description: Ali Jaafar and his sons Mohamed and Yousef cashed in more than 13,000 Massachusetts lottery tickets, prosecutors said, allowing the actual winners to potentially avoid paying taxes or child support.
content: No statistical model could explain it, and when a Massachusetts man and his two sons cashed in more than 13,000 winning lottery tickets worth nearly $21 million over eight years, federal prosecutors and lottery officials said it was anything but luck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $800,000 Homes in California
description: A retreat in the Mojave Desert, a renovated Victorian in Oakland and a farmhouse in Mendocino County.
content: Landers, a small community in the Mojave Desert, is about 20 minutes from the entrance to Joshua Tree National Park. One of its main attractions is Giant Rock, a seven-story boulder that was the focal point of a search for extraterrestrial life in the 1930s, making Landers a magnet for U.F.O. hunters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Teens Are Advocating for Mental Health Days Off School
description: The decline in the mental health of children and adolescents has led to new laws allowing kids to attend to their own self-care.
content: By the time Ben Ballman reached his junior year in high school he was busier — and more anxious — than he had ever been.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Disappointing Melon? Try These Tricks.
description: Treat the fruit like a cucumber (they’re related), and add it to a Greek salad or turn it into a soup, to name just a few ideas.
content: We’ve all done it: selected what we hoped was a lush, sweet honeydew melon only to discover that the interior was firm and flavorless. What to do? Just pretend it’s a cucumber and cut pieces to add to a Greek salad. Purée the flesh with buttermilk, dill and some ice water for a refreshing cold soup. Or lightly smash chunks and dress them with chile crisp to taste, a splash of lime, salt and pepper, and chopped cilantro. Adding cooked shrimp or cubes of firm tofu to that Sichuan mixture would not be a mistake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: The Caldor fire near Sacramento has burned more than 100,000 acres.
description: The blaze, which has been burning for just over a week, grew by more than 30,000 acres this weekend.
content: Crews battling the Caldor fire southwest of Lake Tahoe in California endured another stressful weekend as the fire grew by more than 30,000 acres in just two days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bittel
title: ‘Totally Surprising and Rather Horrifying’: Giant Tortoises Eat Baby Birds
description: For the first time, scientists in the Seychelles captured footage of one of the hulking reptiles stalking and killing a helpless chick.
content: It may be time to retire the phrase “gentle giant.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li
title: Signs bubble up that a Chinese city is growing weary of lockdown.
description: China’s zero-tolerance approach to Covid is starting to wear thin in the eastern city of Yangzhou, much of which has been in a lockdown since the beginning of the month.
content: China’s zero-tolerance approach to Covid is starting to wear thin in the eastern city of Yangzhou, much of which has been in a lockdown since the beginning of the month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: A North Carolina court panel expands voting rights for parolees and people on probation.
description: The 2-1 ruling, in a state Superior Court in Raleigh, restores voting rights to a disproportionately Black group of roughly 56,000 people on parole, probation or supervised release.
content: North Carolina must immediately allow felons who are on parole, probation or supervised release to register to vote, a three-judge panel in a state court said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Workers Don’t Want Their Old Jobs on the Old Terms
description: A pandemic lesson: You can say no to bad pay and conditions.
content: The pandemic disrupted many Americans’ work lives. Some of us — generally highly educated white-collar workers with relatively well-paying jobs — were able to shift to remote work. Millions of other workers, especially many poorly paid service workers, simply saw their jobs disappear when consumers stopped eating out and traveling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: It’s ‘Back to That Isolation Bubble’ for Workers Pining for the Office
description: As coronavirus cases rise and companies keep workplaces closed, frustrated employees can’t wait to return to their cubicles.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Before the pandemic, Roya Joseph’s days at the office were defined by interaction. She looked forward to casual conversations with co-workers, mentorship sessions with managers and periodic, freewheeling chats — known as “teatime” — in the office kitchen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma
title: They Were Protectors in Afghanistan. Now They Need Help.
description: Former soldiers from Nepal have long served as private security guards in war-torn Afghanistan. Amid the chaos, they worry that they can’t get home.
content: KATHMANDU, Nepal — The suicide bomber driving a sedan packed with explosives struck in the early hours of the morning, as the minibus crawled through Kabul’s traffic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: A 6-Year Refit Winds Back the Clock at a Berlin Landmark
description: After a $165 million renovation, the Neue Nationalgalerie looks like it did when it first opened in 1968. That’s exactly the point.
content: BERLIN — The renovations took six years and cost $165 million, but what impressed Julia Büttelmann when she visited the Neue Nationalgalerie on Sunday was that nothing seemed to have changed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: A High-Summer Feast to Forge Connections in the Deep South
description: Matthew Raiford swore he’d never return to his family farm in coastal Georgia. But in breaking that vow, he found a sense of community worth celebrating with a lavish spread.
content: BRUNSWICK, Ga. — It’s not a stretch to say there may have never been a party for a cookbook like the one Matthew Raiford threw on his family farm a few weeks ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Australia should shift its focus away from lockdowns, its prime minister says.
description: Australia, which is battling its worst coronavirus outbreak, must cease lockdowns that attempt to stamp out the virus once the country reaches its initial vaccination target of 70 percent of the eligible population, Prime Minister Scott Morrison said on Monday.
content: Australia, which is battling its worst coronavirus outbreak, must cease lockdowns that attempt to stamp out the virus once the country reaches its initial vaccination target of 70 percent of the eligible population, Prime Minister Scott Morrison said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Afghan Fiasco Raises Hard Questions for Europe
description: Once again, the United States has dragged its NATO allies into an embarrassing mess they had warned against, bringing calls for more autonomy. But the price of independence is steep.
content: BRUSSELS — President Biden says he hears no criticism from America’s allies about the chaotic withdrawal from Afghanistan and the collapse of the government. But the criticism in Europe, at least, is loud and persistent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: A local government in Australia killed its impounded dogs over coronavirus fears.
description: The rural Bourke Shire Council said two of the dogs had become aggressive and the person who regularly found new homes for the animals became unavailable.
content: A rural local government in the state of New South Wales in Australia has put down 15 impounded dogs in a seemingly extreme attempt to keep workers safe from the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: American Vet Returns to Italy to Greet ‘Bambini’ He Last Saw in 1944
description: The daughter of a World War II veteran used the internet to track down three children he was photographed with 77 years ago — after almost firing on them. On Monday, they finally met face to face.
content: BOLOGNA, Italy — The last time Martin Adler saw the three Naldi siblings in person, it was during World War II in the central Italian village of Cassano di Monterenzio, some 40 kilometers south of Bologna, during an Allied offensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthieu Aikins
title: The Taliban holds first meeting of religious leaders since taking Kabul.
description: Hundreds of imams and leaders of religious schools met as the Taliban outlined its vision for education and its new government.
content: The Taliban held their first meeting of religious leaders since retaking Afghanistan’s capital last week, laying out guidelines about religious instructions to hundreds of the nation’s imams and religious school instructors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Climate Change Contributed to Europe’s Deadly Floods, Scientists Find
description: Warming increased the likelihood of the record downpours last month in Germany and Belgium and also made them wetter, according to a study.
content: The violent and deadly flooding in Germany and Belgium last month was an extremely rare event, scientists said Monday, but one that was made more likely by climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Coleman
title: Staging ‘The Glass Menagerie’ on the Fire Escapes That Inspired It
description: At Tennessee Williams’s childhood apartment in St. Louis, one of his most famous works has become an immersive event.
content: ST. LOUIS — There’s a knowing twinkle in Tom Wingfield’s eye.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Morris and Emily Anthes
title: For Some College Students, Remote Learning Is a Game Changer
description: Last year, online classes helped many students with disabilities pursue their education. They want the option to continue.
content: When Daniel Goldberg took his final exams last December, he was attired in little more than a baby-blue hospital gown with an intravenous line snaking out of his arm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon
title: Pfizer, Flooding, Jeopardy: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: David Copperfield’s Wild Ride
description: Armando Iannucci’s adaptation of Dickens’s novel is mad, loving, and brilliant.
content: Armando Iannucci’s adaptation of Dickens’s novel is mad, loving, and brilliant.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Pandemic Has Given Women a New Kind of Rage
description: As Gloria Steinem said, “The truth will set you free. But first it will piss you off.”
content: As Gloria Steinem said, “The truth will set you free. But first it will piss you off.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terri Huggins
title: Email Auto-Responses for Your Mental Health
description: Many of us are struggling with burnout and pandemic frustration and, for some, our out-of-office messages reflect that.
content: Many of us are struggling with burnout and pandemic frustration and, for some, our out-of-office messages reflect that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: 5 Questions About Booster Shots, Answered
description: Health officials recommended last week that Americans who received either the Pfizer or the Moderna coronavirus vaccine receive a third dose to boost their protection against the virus.
content: Health officials recommended last week that Americans who received either the Pfizer or the Moderna coronavirus vaccine receive a third dose to boost their protection against the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by Katherine Schulten
title: Vocabulary in Context: TikTok Food Stars
description: Test your vocabulary and reading comprehension with this quiz based on the Times article “TikTok, the Fastest Way on Earth to Become a Food Star.”
content: Test your vocabulary and reading comprehension with this quiz based on the Times article “TikTok, the Fastest Way on Earth to Become a Food Star.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Tiffany Haddish Would Like to Share Some Facts About Shark Sex
description: This is how you know God is a comedian: Male sharks have two penises.
content: This is how you know God is a comedian: Male sharks have two penises.

title: What You Get for $800,000 in California
description: A retreat in the Mojave Desert, a renovated Victorian in Oakland and a farmhouse in Mendocino County.

author: By The New York Times
title: Deaths and ‘Massive’ Devastation After Tennessee Floods
description: Flash floods cut a path of destruction through Humphreys County over the weekend, scattering cars, ripping homes from their foundations and killing more than 20 people.
content: Flash floods cut a path of destruction through Humphreys County over the weekend, scattering cars, ripping homes from their foundations and killing more than 20 people.

author: By Reuters and Storyful
title: Caldor Fire Burns More than 100,000 Acres in California
description: Burning southwest of Lake Tahoe, the Caldor fire grew by more than 30,000 acres over the weekend. Hundreds of homes have been destroyed by the fire, officials said.
content: Burning southwest of Lake Tahoe, the Caldor fire grew by more than 30,000 acres over the weekend. Hundreds of homes have been destroyed by the fire, officials said.

author: By The New York Times
title: Henri Brings Heavy Rain and Flooding to the Northeast
description: Tropical Storm Henri flooded roadways and knocked out power for thousands in the Northeast. The storm was expected to bring more rain to New England and Mid-Atlantic states as a tropical depression.
content: Tropical Storm Henri flooded roadways and knocked out power for thousands in the Northeast. The storm was expected to bring more rain to New England and Mid-Atlantic states as a tropical depression.

title: Fearful About Afghanistan’s Future
description: An Afghan student writes that she has seen her "dreams destroyed." Other readers discuss what the U.S. should have done and should do now. Also: The "Homecoming" concert in Central Park.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: A Salad Inspired by Barbecue Potato Chips
description: Eric Kim’s latest is destined to be a potluck hit.
content: Imagine I’m the old lady at the end of the bar making my point with a lit Parliament. Ready?
source.name: The New York Times
